source: Growing Gourmet & Medicinal Mushrooms – Contamination & Troubleshooting Extract

vectors_of_contamination.overview: Contamination arises through six primary vectors. Diagnosing the vector is the foundation of solving nearly all contamination issues.

vectors.name: cultivator
vectors.description: Human body carries fungi, bacteria, viruses. Contaminants spread via breath, skin flakes, and touch.
prevention: Wash hands every 20–30 minutes with antibacterial soap.
Disinfect hands regularly with 80% isopropyl alcohol.

vectors.name: air
vectors.description: Air is a reservoir of suspended microorganisms. Personnel movement disturbs settled contaminants.
prevention: Use ≥3 doorways before the sterile lab.
Positive-pressure air with micron filtration is ideal.
"Still-air" rooms use disinfectant mist to settle particulates.
Ensure fresh-air exchange to avoid CO₂ buildup (promotes contaminant growth).

vectors.name: media
vectors.description: Improperly prepared or sterilized substrates become vectors themselves.

vectors.name: tools
vectors.description: Unclean scalpels, jars, blades, and surfaces introduce contaminants.
prevention: Keep instruments in disinfectant baths or flame-sterilize.

vectors.name: inoculum
vectors.description: Contaminated agar, liquid culture, or transfers propagate contamination into otherwise clean media.
prevention: Use clean transfer technique inside sterile workflow.

vectors.name: mobile_contamination_units
vectors.description: Mites, flies, and other small organisms acting as carriers.
prevention: Control humidity to reduce mold attractiveness.

diagnostic_principles.blank_controls: Always leave at least one jar, plate, or bag uninoculated each batch. If blanks contaminate, the problem is media prep—not inoculation.
diagnostic_principles.multi_symptom_problems: One environmental error (e.g., high humidity) can produce multiple symptoms: bacterial blotch, green mold, mites feeding on mold, flies transporting mites, deformed fruiting bodies, and short shelf-life.
diagnostic_principles.root_cause_focus: Correct the underlying vector rather than the visible contaminant.

symptoms: Flies carrying mites and mold spores
solutions: Reduce and balance humidity according to species needs.
Avoid sustained wetness on mushroom surfaces.

symptoms: High presence of Sciarid or Phorid flies
Damage to mycelium and fruiting bodies
likely_causes: High humidity post-soak (wood substrates highly susceptible)
solutions: Use sticky traps and bug lights at entrances.
Do not use pesticides (discouraged by text).
Improve environmental hygiene and air barriers.

hygiene_practices: Wash hands frequently or wear gloves.
Growing room staff should not mix with lab personnel.
Remove contamination once per day; handler should not return to work with clean substrates.
Daily wash-downs of ceilings, walls, and floors.
post_contamination_handling: Treat yourself as contaminated once you have handled contaminated cultures.
Dispose of contaminated blocks at end of workday when possible.
Use non-production staff for early-day contamination disposal.
